p: The most striking source of variation in denitrification potential was time, with average measurements varying nearly 8-fold among seasons and years ( Fig 7 and Table 2). Nevertheless, denitrification potential in removal sites decreased significantly by approximately 50% relative to intact Phragmites-dominated reference locations ( Fig 7 and Table 2, p = 0.0471). This effect remained remarkably constant two years following initial herbicide application ( Fig 7). With the exception of anomalously high denitrification potential measurements at the reference Typha sites in September 2011, denitrification potentials were consistently highest in Phragmites-dominated sites, and were significantly higher than Typha-dominated sites in Ramshorn Marsh at Î± = 0.10 ( Table 2).
